results.headline: Desperate Years: To Be Young, British and Lacking
results.summary_short: Inspired by an Oscar Wilde fairy tale, “The Selfish Giant” depicts two young friends navigating their bleak working-class landscape in Northern England.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Selfish Giant

results.headline: Backward to Somewhere
results.summary_short: “The Past,” the new film from the Iranian director of “A Separation,” looks at a range of personal struggles in suburban Paris.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Past

results.headline: A Dream Factory for a Benighted China
results.summary_short: “Personal Tailor,” a blend of comedy and satire, centers on a fantasy fabrication service that provides wealthy clients with a taste of the lives they have always wanted.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Personal Tailor

results.display_title: All the Light in the Sky
results.headline: An Aging Actress Faces the Mirror
results.summary_short: “All the Light in the Sky” asks questions about human nature, the march of time and global warming.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All the Light in the Sky

results.headline: Disembodied, but, Oh, What a Voice
results.summary_short: “Her,” directed by Spike Jonze, centers on a lonely soul who is drawn out by the female voice of his computer operating system.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Her

results.headline: Like a Home Renovation, but With Vermeers
results.summary_short: “The New Rijksmuseum,” a documentary about that museum’s decade-long redesign, lingers on the logistical and bureaucratic details of the process.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The New Rijksmuseum, Part 2

results.headline: Ron Burgundy’s Boob Tube Goes 24 Hours a Day
results.summary_short: Will Ferrell stars in “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues,” a sequel now set in the 1980s and the era of cable.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues

results.headline: Amid Tortures Of the Flesh, A Naïve Crush
results.summary_short: “Paradise: Hope,” the third installment in Ulrich Seidl’s grim film trilogy, centers on an adolescent girl who is sent to a summer weight-loss camp.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paradise: Hope

results.headline: Two Personal Stories Become One Film
results.summary_short: The Polish director and cinematographer Wojciech Staron turns the camera on his own family in “Two Lessons.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Lessons

results.headline: Special Matriarchal Lessons
results.summary_short: With “Tyler Perry’s A Madea Christmas,” Mr. Perry serves up his female alter ego in a holiday film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's A Madea Christmas

results.headline: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner. No, Don’t.
results.summary_short: “What’s in a Name?,” directed by Matthieu Delaporte and Alexandre de la Patellière, centers on a fractious dinner party.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Prénom

results.headline: A Filmmaker’s Hold on His Muse
results.summary_short: “Liv and Ingmar: Painfully Connected” documents the relationship between Liv Ullmann and Ingmar Bergman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Liv & Ingmar: Painfully Connected

results.headline: Saving a Newborn One Breath at a Time
results.summary_short: In “Hours,” Paul Walker of “The Fast and the Furious” fame plays a man trying to keep his fragile daughter alive after Hurricane Katrina.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hours

results.headline: Big Hair, Bad Scams, Motormouths
results.summary_short: “American Hustle,” starring Christian Bale and Amy Adams, may be about a famous federal sting, but it’s also a love story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Hustle

results.headline: Young, Naïve and Selling Sex
results.summary_short: “Tricked” looks at women forced into prostitution in the United States and their unpunished exploiters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tricked

results.headline: Good Heavens, They’re Atheists
results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Unbelievers,” the prominent secularists Richard Dawkins and Lawrence Krauss travel the world accompanied by a rock soundtrack.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unbelievers

results.display_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug
results.headline: In the Middle of Middle-earth
results.summary_short: Part 2 of Peter Jackson’s trilogy based on the one-part “Hobbit,” “The Desolation of Smaug,” has lots of battles, an original character and Orlando Bloom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug

results.headline: He Wants Her Back. She’s Not Interested.
results.summary_short: In “Some Velvet Morning,” directed by Neil LaBute, a man rings a former lover’s doorbell and tells her he has left his wife.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Some Velvet Morning

results.headline: An Unbeliever in Disney World
results.summary_short: In the Disney movie “Saving Mr. Banks,” Walt Disney is — spoiler alert — a nice guy trying to win over the uptight creator of “Mary Poppins,” P. L. Travers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saving Mr. Banks

results.headline: What Happens When the Kids Wander Off
results.summary_short: In “Here Comes the Devil,” directed by Adrián García Bogliano, a family falls apart after a mysterious night on a forbidding hillside.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Here Comes the Devil
